subject: idempotence Re: [junit] Article That Should Help Testing: "Five Habits of Highly
msgSnippet: ... http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2006/08/24/five-habits-of-highly-profitable-developers.html ... JUnit s help. ... The main idea is when behavior methods
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Pat Farrell <pfarrell@...> wrote:
>
> robertjmiller_jgs wrote:
> > Today, I have a test related article being published on java.net:
> > "Five Habits of Highly Profitable Software Developers"
> >
http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2006/08/24/five-habits-of-highly-profitable-developers.html

>
> It is not clear to me if this article is aimed at JUnit development, or
> the business objects that are being tested and developed with
JUnit's help.
>
> The first example, the CustomerAccount is clearly a business object.
>
> Yet the Habit 2 is clearly about Junit methods:
> public void testRequestedPasswordIsNotValid
> BecauseItMustBeDifferentThanTheUsername()
>
> But my big question is that is the meaning of Habit 5.
> It appears to be arguing in favor of implementing idempotent state,
> which while useful in some cases, is not generally a characteristic of
> business objects.
>
> Am I missing something?

The main idea is when behavior methods perform their logic independent
of other behavior methods they are more likely to be used, tested, and
understood correctly. For a given set of data (state), the behavior
methods should return the correct answer regardless of what order they
were called in. Does that clarify Habit 5?

Thanks for the feedback,
Rob Miller

> --
> Pat Farrell
> http://www.pfarrell.com/
>
